The internet permits like-minded people with little information, or misinformation, to communicate freely without a "reality" check, thus permitting a consensus to form and emotions to be fanned without deflation. Nor do people communicate face-to-face, or even ear-to-ear. For example, all of the communications described in the article above other than the actual "Let him die" incident occurred in "virtual" reality. Personal contact serves as a kind of friction to slow down the mob; in most cases, by injecting a little empathy into the discussion by forcing people to confront reality -- the reality of other people. On the internet, that never occurs.

The story about Paul and Snyder is awful, and not surprising given Paul's narcissism; but I wonder if all those who were cheering, particularly the twenty-somethings, would have felt as confident about their views if they'd had to explain those sentiments to a doctor or teacher. One of my cousins is married to a "truther" (yes, really) who spent hours son on the internet feeding his fantasies about the WTC collapse. Finally, one night, at a holiday dinner, the entire family confronted him with facts (one family member was related to one of the engineers who'd planned the buildings, and explained, in detail, how the collapse had occurred). We heard no more fantasies from the "truther".

I think that wild feelings -- fear, rage, hatred -- are being fanned by the Republican elite for its own selfish purposes, and that the ability to communicate without a reality check promotes such herd violence. Yes, the Republican elite doesn't care if people die; but that is nothing new. What is new is that the people whom the elites disregard are joining the battle that will lead to their own demise, and that electronic communication is making such mass suicide all too easy.
The real issues are "who is worthy of charity?" and "who decides to give his money to charity?"

If one stands back from this debate within the United States, the truly amazing part emerges. How is that every other industrial democracy has SOLVED the problem of providing universal public health care, and in a manner which (without exception) provides better overall care for less money per capita.

Put another way, what is it about American society and/or the American psyche which insists on rejecting over a dozen proven, successful and economic solutions to this problem simply, it would seem, because none were "made in America"? Is the nation really that insular?

One of the issues that I see tangled up in the hypothetical about the ill, intentionally uninsured person is that that person's "choices" puts others in difficult situations:  I doubt the health care folks at the ER want to put him out on the street. It almost seems to me a little bit analogous to "suicide by cop."  Which leads me to the thinking about how we object to being pulled into somebody else's unhealthy ways of interfacing with the world in that situation, and hence there is social pressure on people not to do that.  Maybe we need more social pressure around the issue of carrying adequate health insurance if we can afford it.  Maybe that's the best way to reduce the occurrence of the fact pattern in the hypothetical, to diminish the issue of mandates (if people are buying adequate insurance voluntarily, there is less reliance on a mandate), and to reduce the number of situations in which we are faced with having to pay for the uninsureds' medical care through piecemeal approaches.

A relatively short time ago, the tea party and their Republican buddies were attacking the proponents of the health care act as setting up "death panels."  So I find it ironic that now we see those same people clammoring to let the uninsured die. I thought "pro-life" meant that you valued all life. What the Republicans fail to grasp is that many of those who are finding themselves unemployed and uninsured as a result of the economic downturn represent plenty of people from their own party. Do they think their harsh rhetoric is winning them any new voters? Or are they planning on disenfranchising the unemployed and uninsured along with minorities, students, women, the poor etc. as they continue to try to pass voter ID laws in our states.

The best you can do is 43.75%. There are an infinite number of ways of doing this (assuming fractional bets). For example your first bet can be 0, 1 , 2, 1000, 1999, 2000, and many, many others. (There are many first bets that it can't be, like 600)
To prove this, I looked at it from the end of the round and then back, computing the win percentage at each round. Let w = $4500

0 bets left:

if I have w ($4500) or more, I win, or 100%. If I have $0 or more (but less than w) I loose, or 0%. Results: 1 w or more => 1, 0w or more (but less than 1w)=> 0

1 bet left:

Divide the space (0 to w) into 2^numBets, or 2 spaces. If I have 1/2 w or more, I can bet just enough to make w if I win. I therefore have a 50% chance of winning (or 1/2). If I have less than 1/2W, no matter how much I bet, I can't win enough to end up with w, so I loose, 0%. As always, if I have w or more, don't bet and I win, 100%. Results: 1w or more => 1, 1/2 w or more => 1/2. 0 w or more => 0.

2 bets left:

Divide the space (0 to w) into 2^numBets, or 4 spaces. If I have 3/4 w or more, I can bet just enough to make w. If I win, I'll have w and if I loose I'll have w/2 or more with 1 bet left. Using the percentage win from the "1 bet left" case, I see that my chances of winning is 1/2 (100%) + 1/2 (50%) or 75% or 3/4.
If I have 2/4w or more (but less than 3/4w) my chance of winning is 50%. I can do this several ways. I can bet nothing and then follow the strategy for "1 bet left" above. Or, I can bet enough to make w. If I loose that bet I'll have less then 1/2 w so chance of winning is 50%. If I am dumb, I bet an amount that doesn't make w if I win, but drops me below 1/2w if I loose. Then my chance is 25%. So I have to bet either a little or a lot on my first bet.

(to be continued)

(continued, sorry it's so long)

Like wise if I have 1/4w or more (but less than 2/4w) my chance is 1/4, and below 1/4w it's 0.
Results: 1w or more => 1, 3/4 w or more => 3/4, 2/4 w or more => 2/4, 1/4 w or more => 1/4, 0w or more => 0.

n bets left:

Divide the space (0 to w) into 2^n spaces. Let N = 2^n.
Results: 1w or more => 1, w(N-1)/N or more => (N-1)/N ...w (2/N) => 2/N, w/N or more => 1/N

----------
Our case, we have $2000, or (0.44444...)(w). For 7 bets, N = 128. 56/128 = 0.4375 and 57/128 = 0.443131... so or best chance is 56/128 or 43.75%. There are an infinit number of ways of doing this (assuming fractional bets). Your first bet can be 0 or 1000 or 2000. However, there are many dumb first bets. If you you bet 600, you chance of winning is only 42.97.. % assuming you bet brilliantly after that. (If you won the $600 dollor bet you'd have 2600 and 6 bets and if you lost you'd have $1400 and 6 bets)
If you look at all posible first bets [0,2000] there are 28 bad regions similar to the 2/4w case on 2 bets left.

Why so much hatred? This guy is doing something that most professional athletes has never done - he and not the promoters have control over his income. The article wasn't so much about his boxing skills. It was really about his business skills.

Moreover, people are complaining about how much money he's making. Is not this a capitalist society? The reason he makes more money than teachers and firemans is because not too many people reach his skill level. If you are not satisfied with your pay, become a boxer and see for yourself how hard it really is.

David wrote "The problem with Mayweather is that he is dumb financially." Sir, did we read the same article? Name one athlete in any sport who has done what he did with the money? Tom Brady? Kobe Bryant? Roger Staubach? Any tennis player? What about a baseball player?

Moreover, how many athletes have a former Swiss banker as a finacial advisor? Then to make the comment about child support tab would bring him down in one breath while wishing him success in another breath is the epitome of irony.

This man doesn't have anything to prove. And if anyone is bent out of shape about the money he's being paid, no problem. This is America. As long as you have a high speed internet connection, a unique idea, and a well laid out business plan, you too can enjoy the benefits of living in a place where capitalism is the order of the day.
